Award.AwardTitle: Spin as a Probe into the Structure of the Universe
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is now a well-established fact that nucleons, protons and neutrons, are made up of more elementary particles called quarks. The main physics program supported by this grant is to measure how the magnetic moments of quarks contribute to the total magnetic moment of the proton, along with contributions from other subatomic particles inside the proton. In addition, this grant will support research on an experiment at Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, labeled E989, which will precisely measure the magnetic moment of a fundamental particle, the muon, which is like an electron but with more mass. The goal of these experiments is to compare experimental result with theoretical predictions from the so-called Standard Model of Particle Physics. The studies described here will provide graduate students with the necessary tools and knowledge to obtain post-doctoral work at other large colliders or smaller non-accelerator based collaborations. Undergraduate students funded by this award will continue to have the rare opportunity to experience the scientific culture and participate in experiments at National Laboratories.

The studies of proton spin structure measurements will be carried out at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory. Longitudinally and transversely polarized proton beams necessary for these experiments are only available at RHIC. Jet reconstruction techniques will be used to measure asymmetries sensitive to the gluon helicity and quark transversity distributions. This award will also support the new g-2 experiment (E989) at the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory, which proposes to measure the muon anomalous magnetic moment to 0.14 parts per million. A deviation from the Standard Model prediction at the observed level could be explained by several Beyond the Standard Model (BSM) scenarios and the improved precision will significantly constrain key parameters in supersymmetry, one of the most widely discussed BSM models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spin is a fundamental characteristic of matter, much like mass and charge, that defines how particles interact with each other. Spin is regularly exploited in technology, for example in the development of quantum computers, in spintronics based memory disks and nuclear magnetic resonance imaging machines. The spin of a particle manifests as a type of angular momentum and because the total angular momentum of a system must be conserved these spin effects provide a unique view into the underlying structure of the universe. For example, physicists have known for nearly fifty years that the protons and neutrons that serve as building blocks for our visible universe are constructed from smaller, more fundamental particles called quarks and gluons. Yet we still don't fully understand how the spin of the quarks and gluons combine to produce the total spin of the proton.

This award provided support for the Kentucky RHIC Spin group, consisting of the principal investigator, two graduate and one undergraduate student, to pursue proton spin structure measurements at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) at Brookhaven National Laboratory.  RHIC is the only facility in the world capable of accelerating and colliding the high energy polarized proton beams necessary to perform these experiments. The Kentucky group used clusters of particles, called jets, to measure asymmetries sensitive to the gluon and quark spin distributions inside the proton. The spin program at RHIC was the first to measure a significant gluon contribution to the spin of the proton. The Kentucky group continued this effort by pushing these measurements into a regime where the density of gluons inside the proton is rapidly increasing. The new findings tell a very similar story, that  as much as a third of the proton spin appears to come from the gluon polarization. 

In addition to gluon studies the Kentucky group pioneered measurements that are sensitive to the way transversely polarized quarks fragment into the particles we observe in our detectors. These signals clearly show that the spatial pattern of the final state particles is correlated with the initial direction of the quark spin!  This type of correlation was first discovered in electron-proton and electron-positron collisions,  but  has never been isolated and extracted in proton-proton collisions. These measurements provide critical information about how this spin dependent fragmentation process changes with the nature and energy of the colliding beams.

The broader impacts resulting from this funding are the exposure and education of students to fundamental nuclear physics. The studies described here provide graduate students with the necessary tools and knowledge to obtain post-doctoral work on a wide variety of nuclear physics experiments, thereby supporting the future of our discipline and the operation of our national laboratories. The impact is not limited to the field of nuclear physics. Because the training in computing, detector technologies and problem solving is very broad, allowing students pursue careers in the private sector where they can make significant contributions at technology start-ups, financial institutions and science policy agencies. For example, the undergraduate student funded by this proposal currently works at Google, while one of the graduate students is a professor a state univeristy in eastern Kentucky.  Both of ttese students used similar research experiences, experiences made possible by this grant funding, to serve different scientific goals and populations.
